bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank F. Law, December 31, 1941

div1.p: Hench describes the display of the Cornwell paintings at the Mayo Clinic. He would be pleased to attend future unveilings of other paintings in the series. Hench mentions the publication of his yellow fever article in the Mayo Clinic Proceedings.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank F. Law, December 31, 1941
div1.opener:
Y F. Copy to Kellogg &
Cornwell
December 31, 1941
Mr. Frank F. Law
John Wyeth and Brother
1600 Arch Street
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
My dear Mr. Law:
div1.p:
As I believe I told you, I have a yellow fever exhibit in the Mayo Clinic
Library. The two oil sketchez of Cornwell, the final colored painting, Cornwell's
crayon sketch of Walter Reed and many other items are exhibited. Unfortunately,
the walls of the main room of the library are of a decorative type of plaster which
will not permit hanging photographs. Therefore, much of the material was put in
a display cabinet, as you will see by the enclosed photograph, right underneath
the portrait of Dr. Nill. In this cabinet we have autographed pictures of Moran,
and Gorgas, actual letters of Walter Reed, Carroll and others and my yellow fever
reprint displayed in full, also three enlargements of Mr. Cornwell's--one of him on a
ladder taking a photograph of the Finlay statue, one of a courtyard in Havana which
served as a basis for his “Cuban version” and one other which he sent, also a picture
taken at the Cleveland unveiling. I thought you would like to see these. I am
sending a set also to Mr. Cornwell and to Mr. Kellogg. Would you mind showing yours
to Mr. Withington? Should he wish a set I shall be glad to send it.

Because of the difficulty in the matter of the walls, the oil sketches
had to be hung in a corridor in the library but this is in a very prominent place,
as it is the corridor connecting the main room and the study rooms, through which
all the doctors go. We have had many nice comments on the exhibit.

Mr. Kellogg pleased me greatly by suggesting that I might be asked to go
as the guest of your company to the unveiling of the painting held in connection
with some medical meeting there this Fall. I am certainly glad to accept and unless
the war interferes will certainly hold this tentative date open. I will send you
shortly a few more reprints of our article on yellow fever as it appeared in the
Proceedings of the Staff Meetings of the Mayo Clinic.

I am taking the liberty of sending Mr. Kellogg and Mr. Cornwell each a
copy of this letter and also a set of the snapshots.

My article in the Proceedings will of course be bound in all the bound
volumes of the Clinic Proceedings but will not appear in the annual Mayo Clinic
Volume. That Volume is a great condensation of the material which appears here
yearly. Many excellent articles do not appear except by title. My paper on yellow
fever will appear by title but not otherwise as Saunders likes to include only
Mr. Frank F. Law
- 2 -
December 31, 1941
material relating to new discoveries or to treatment. You will be interested
to know that the circulation of the Proceedings of the Mayo Clinic Staff Meetings
is the highest in America of the bonafide medical publications next to the Journal
of the A.M.A. The A.M.A. circulation is 99,000; that of our Proceedings is 20,000;
the Medical Clinics of North America 13,000; American Journal of Obstetrics and
Gynecology 5,200; Annals of Internal Medicine 5,000. These figures of course do not
include the throw away or free journals. So you will see that my article will
reach a pretty good class of medical readers.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
(To Mr. Kellogg)
P. S. Thanks for sending me the address of Mr. Lambert. I hope to see
him in Chicago on my way back from New York and Washington next month. You sent
me addresses of two of Major Reed's granddaughters. I thought there was only one.
Does Mrs. Monro live in Singapore, Malay, Straits Settlement? That is the one
now being attacked. If so she may be in for a hell of a time.
P.S.H.
